text: I like it. I mainly use the Dance extension in VSCode, though. It mimics the same style. As to learning, it was mainly just jumping in and trying things. I'm a lot better at VimGolf in Kakoune than in Vim (been using Vim for a while, but I never was an expert).

text: You know ... There's this device called a mouse. It frees your mind from remembering hundreds of hotkeys and setting configurations.:troll:

elements.text: You know ... There's this device called a mouse. It frees your mind from remembering hundreds of hotkeys and setting configurations.

text: :smile_cat:  Instead, you need to remember where that command was in some nested menu or what some fiddly icon means. One of the advantages of the Kakoune style is that it cuts down on the "mind clutter". The set of movement, selection, and text manipulation commands is reasonably small, and (like Julia) they compose well. For many of the options, there's a clippy-style helper that shows you the options available (go ahead and laugh, but it really is helpful). These are the reasons I've been able to up my movement and text-manipulation game. In Vim (or Emacs Evil or VSCodeVim), I could do the basics, but I never could remember the fancy stuff.
